contentrichtext.text: {{For|context|Bee (mythology)}} {{Cleanup-rewrite|date=February 2012}} The '''Thriae''' or '''Thriai''' were [[nymphs]], three virginal sisters, one of a number of such triads ("maiden trinities" [[Jane Ellen Harrison]] called them) in [[Greek mythology]].<ref>[[Hesiod]]'s ''[[Theogony]]'' gives the [[Gorgon]], the [[Horae]], the [[Moirai]], and the [[Charites]]; later myth adds the [[Erinyes]], the [[Graiae]], the [[Siren]]s, the [[Hesperides]], and [[cult (religion)|Greek cult]] has given more: see the list in Scheinberg 1979:2.</ref> They received names [[Melaina]] ("the Black"), [[Kleodora]] ("Famed for her Gift"), and [[Daphnis (nymph)|Daphnis]] ("Laurel"); however, in the page in the Corycian nymphs, the third sister is listed as Corycia. They were the three [[Naiad]]s ([[nymph]]s) of the sacred springs of the [[Corycian Cave]] of [[Mount Parnassus]] in [[Phocis]]. Corycia was the sister whom the [[Corycian Cave]] was named after. She was the mother of [[Lycoreus]] with [[Apollo]]. Kleodora was loved by [[Poseidon]]. With Poseidon (or Kleopompos) she was the mother of Parnassos, who founded the city of Parnassus. ([[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]] 10.6.13). Melaina was loved by [[Apollo]], bearing him [[Delphus|Delphos]]. Another tradition names [[Thyia]] as the mother of Delphos. Her name meant "the black," suggesting she presides over [[Underworld#Greek mythology|subterranean]] nymphs. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *Scheinberg, Susan 1979. "The Bee Maidens of the Homeric Hymn to Hermes" Harvard Studies in Classical Philology 83 (1979), pp. 1â€“28. [[Category:Nymphs]] [[Category:Greek mythology]]
